title: Sales Wants a Detour
description: Sales wants a feature for a big prospect that doesn't fit the roadmap. Engineering is maxed out and users want other stuff.

choices.text: Say no to sales for now, using user data and the agreed roadmap.
Say yes, reshuffle the roadmap, and try to close the deal fast.
Offer a compromise: a lighter version or workaround, revisit if the deal closes.

title: Ship It or Learn First?
description: You have a strong feature idea but little user research. Eng has a gap next sprint and could build it, but design wants more discovery.

choices.text: Pause and run real discovery with users, even if you miss the sprint window.
Greenlight a minimal version now and learn from real usage.
Split the sprint: some engineers build a spike, you and design do scrappy research in parallel.

title: Tech Debt vs Shiny Stuff
description: Engineering wants a tech-debt sprint. Stakeholders want shiny features.

choices.text: Back engineering fully, commit the sprint to tech debt, and translate the benefits for stakeholders.
Compromise: carve out a small part for tech debt, rest for visible features.
Ask engineering to squeeze tech debt into the background, focus sprint on visible wins.

title: Power Users vs Newbies
description: Power users want advanced controls that complicate the UI. New users are struggling with the basics.

choices.text: Prioritize simplifying core flows for new users, postpone advanced features.
Ship advanced options fast for power users, accept extra complexity.
Design a progressive setup: keep default simple, add discoverable advanced controls.

title: Experiment Flopped
description: You pushed for an experiment that didn’t move the metrics. Leadership is asking if it was a waste of time.

choices.text: Frame it as a clear learning, use the data to show what you now know and how it changes the roadmap.
Quietly move on and avoid drawing attention to the flop.
Push for more tries on the same idea, argue it wasn’t given a fair chance.

title: Founder’s Pet Feature
description: The founder wants a pet feature based on one conversation. You know it doesn’t fit the strategy or data.

choices.text: Push back with data and explain why it doesn’t fit the current priorities.
Agree to fit a small version into the roadmap soon to keep alignment high.
Offer to test the idea quickly with a prototype or user interviews before committing eng time.

title: Delegation or Bottleneck?
description: You’re stretched thin across squads. One team wants you in every meeting and decision.

choices.text: Stay deeply involved with that team and accept other areas will move slower.
Empower a lead in the team to own more decisions and step back from most meetings.
Create clearer decision frameworks so teams can move with less of your direct involvement.
